title: Pantheon
description:
The Pantheon made a big impression on me. What struck me most was its beauty and how well it has survived for nearly two thousand years.

I started thinking about modern building techniques and what it would take to create something that could last that long.

The Colosseum was looted for stone and metal, so building mainly with concrete seems wise. Instead of iron rebar, we could use carbon-fiber reinforcement—it lasts longer and has little value to looters.

Inside, the design could feature beautiful colors and tiles, but not valuable materials that are easy to remove. The building should function even without electricity or running water. The Pantheon’s oculus provides light when electric systems fail; similarly, a modern version could use natural light and low-power LEDs when power is available. Modern heating could be included, but we should also consider how to keep the building comfortable when power is lost—perhaps this kind of structure is best suited to warmer climates.

The Pantheon’s survival also owes much to its conversion into a church. Because it remained in continuous use, it was maintained over the centuries.

Its size and beauty are another reason people have preserved it—citizens are proud of it and don’t want to see it destroyed. A modern equivalent, I think, would be a public space such as a theater, concert hall, or town meeting venue. With good acoustics and a modest stage, it could host many types of gatherings—a place where people enjoy coming together and feel civic pride.

Such a building should be located in a populated city where people can walk to it, but not in an area so valuable that developers would want to replace it with high-rises.

There could be small caretaker rooms built into the structure and large doors to secure it in times of trouble. And, like the Pantheon, it should have a public square in front—a gathering space that adds to its sense of importance and permanence.

images.title: Pantheon
images.description: The Pantheon has a grand entrance is classic Roman style, with columns and a square in front.
As you get closer you the scale becomes apparent.
The interior is well perserved.  When it is open for tourists it is very popular. It is still used as a church.

The dome has a 9 foot diameter hole in the middle called the oculus. It lights the interior. There are small holes in the floor to drain the rain.  They blend into the design and are hard to notice.  I was looking for them and found them but Kathleen didn't notice until I pointed them out.

The building is made of concrete instead of stone like the Colosseum. The dome is thinner than the lower walls and light pumice is mixed in.  The hollows also lighten the load.
I've seen the Pantheon twice the first time with Alex and Agatha (bottom right) in April 2017, then with Kathleen and Elisabeth in Jun 2019.
The sides of the building don't look like much.  Notice there are windows and a back room.

The city has grow higher since the Patheon was built, by comparing the street level with the Pantheon level.  The Roman Forum is an extreme example.

nWikipidea:

"As the ground around buildings rose, residents simply paved over the debris that was too much to remove. Its final travertine paving, still visible, dates from the reign of Augustus. Excavations in the 19th century revealed one layer on top of another."
The city band appeared in the square playing classic Italian songs.  We watched and listened to Funiculì, funiculà. which I enjoyed along with the crowd.
